Absolutely save for IPS.
I sit at the computer for 8+ hours every day for work and in the office I've got a Lenovo ThinkVision T27i-10.
It's a 1080p 60Hz IPS panel.

At home I've got a Samsung Odyssey G5. It's a 1440p 144Hz VN Curved display, both are 27" and cost about the same.

The display at work gives me no trouble at all, staring at it all day.
At home I take breaks. It's wonderful having the increased resolution for productivity purposes, but the ergonomics and panel quality is just vastly different.

It's not bad of course and I don't regret the purchase, but on the other hand, I should've splurged ~100€ more and got an 1440p IPS panel. I don't need the high refresh rate anyways.

>>90764338
>will there be a noticeable decrease in my computer's temperatures?
Unlikely unless it's really, really cold out.
>Could moisture from the air cause damage?
Moisture in the air isn't going to do anything to your computer. Moisture condensing inside your computer could, but that would only be an issue if the air getting pulled into the computer is warmer than the air inside your computer.
Do you get condensation on the outside of a cup of hot coffee, or on the outside of a cold glass of iced tea?

>>90763987
Mullvad or PIA. Make sure to bind the VPN interface in qBittorrent advanced settings, otherwise the program sometimes connects to peers using VPN and home IP at the same time.

After you have set up the VPN and client, test if there are any leaks. To do this, you add a torrent of one of those websites. They are monitoring the torrent and will show you every client that connects to them.

https://bash (dot) ws/torrent-leak-test
https://www.whatismyip.net/tools/torrent-ip-checker/index.php
https://torguard.net/checkmytorrentipaddress.php

Protip: If you want higher speeds, forward a port. Mullvad and PIA both allow this, while NordVPN and Surfshark, for example, do not. They will assign you a random port and you copy that port into your qBittorrent settings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90771219
Depends on whatever device you're playing video from. If the device and the device's network can't handle the original quality video, then you may run into issues.

Therefore, if you are using newish (5 years or newer?) hardware to watch the videos, and you're doing it just at your home, you should be fine. Android and iOS will be a mixed bag due to codec support.

>N3520
This is going to be your problem. If your device can't handle the original quality stream, your CPU will have to transcode, which this CPU will likely struggle with.

Worth a shot though, learn something new? At least make sure you plug it in to ethernet, 2.4GHz wifi will slow it down really bad and be unusable.

>>90771550
I mostly agree with >>90772384 but really all you need is to learn all the functions of a multimeter and a capacitance tester for diagnosis. It's *usually* a capacitor. If it's not, it's probably not worth even attempting to fix.

Replacing components, on the other hand, is another topic entirely.

>>90777055
Not usually. Age shouldn't matter, but usage does.
Fragmentation hurts performance.
For all CMR drives Windows automatic defragging should be enough to ensure decent performance for most uses other than a scratch disk (heavy use temp storage) or something.
Unfortunately SMR has been a thing for ~8y now since Seagate released their Archive drives and it has taken over the budget range of many drives. All manufacturers are making SMR these days so you gotta be careful. Low capacity 3.5", virtually all 2.5" drives, etc are usually SMR. If you're using an SMR drive it's normal for write performance to slow down massively on those after putting lots of data on it.

posts.com:
The """""debate""""" over whether AI Art is Art is not important. This entire argument is based on the fragility of artists who are now using the non-existent "It's copyright, bro" argument as a thin veil to hide their grasp at self preservation.
AI Art is not a threat to professional artists. It is not going to replace as many jobs as people think. Even if companies decided to wholesale use AI, they would still need artists and concept designers to fix up the AI generated images.
The people who are threatened by AI are the Amateurs. The Talentless. The Unoriginal. The Boring The "Please subscribe to my patreon and donate" types. The people threatened by AI are the dregs, not the professionals. The entire debate is effectively about money, and when you poke the nest long enough, the eventually let it spill that they are concerned it will take their careers.
First of all, this goes against the entirety of what art is supposed to be. If "human expression" is so important, you'll always have people who want you. You will always have a market. Artistry (As least the kind they are seething about) is not going to be a career. Very few artists made a straight-up living, less a fortune, from commissions. If human expression is the issue, the entire debate wouldn't centre around whether or not they make a living. Pretty much all artists in history were poor schizos.

AI is a potentially incredible tool. Most artists nowadays are already technophiles with their obsessive use or photoshop and digital tools. AI is another tool in that belt. It's not a direct threat to any artist worth their shit.

Budget: i5 13400F, R5 7600 (whichever is cheapest)

>RECOMMENDED GPU PERFORMANCE LEVEL
Do NOT buy from any second hand sources (it is either scalped or used).
1440p: RX 6800/XT, RTX 3080; budget: RX 6650XT, RTX 3060 Ti FE, RX 6700 XT
2160p: RTX 4090, 7900XTX; alternative: RX 6950/XT, RTX 3090, budget: RTX 3080 12GB, RX 6800/XT

Budget: 16gb DDR4 3600 MT/s CL18, CL14 with Ryzen for CPU limited games
Standard: 32gb DDR5 6000 MT/s CL30, strongly advised to avoid mixing xmp kits
High end: 64gb+ DDR5 6000 MT/s CL30, strongly advised to avoid mixing xmp kits.

Avoid OLED TVs. Keep pixel density in mind when choosing a monitor size (137+ PPI is good, ~200 is ideal though rare and expensive).

High end: High refresh rate 4k panels with MiniLED, g-sync ultimate modules, 10-bit, and so on (PG32UQX is the best currently). Look for VESA DisplayHDR 1400 certification.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90776494
Audio engineers test on multiple systems to make sure their mix sounds good on everything. Desktop setups, home theater setups, cars, and headphones, and earbuds are all listened to when audio is being designed by professionals. The initial mix is made on studio monitors in a sound treated rooms, and they they adjust for multiple listening devices after that. Sometimes different audio mixes exist, and they sound a bit different. For example: The theatrical release of movie audio is usually mixed differently from what you get at home on Blu-ray or streaming

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90764825
Even if you were right about year being redundant (which i disagree with, i post on boards with 2 year old threads still up), having YY first still makes sense as it's the least ambiguous number pair.
>07/06/23
You see this date on a post and you need to look for other context to figure out whether it's MMDDYY or DDMMYY.
>23/06/07
You see this on a post and you know it's YYMMDD, since nobody uses YYDDMM. Depending on the thread/board it might still be ambiguous (is this the 23rd of june, 2007?) but the chance of ambiguity is far lower and the amount of context needed to disambiguate is most often less.

There is simply no good reason not to use YYMMDD, other than people being attached to "their" locale.

The purpose of FuschiaOS is to make a flexible operating system that identifies the hardware architecture and adapts to it. The idea is to create one OS (one code) that works for:

> smart tvs
> smart speakers
> smart watches
> smartphones
> personal computers
> etc...

It would work on Chromebook and Android devices without relying on the underlying APIs (android API) and has its own kernel (microkernel). If the project comes to maturity and works as a replacement for android i expect it to reshape the programming languages popularity ranking for GUI programming on these devices. The native languages of this OS would be:
> C/C++
> Dart
> Go
> Rust

With native support for Flutter which would not rely on Skiia as a rendering engine anymore.

.NET Core is not truly cross platform for desktop GUIs, anyone who tells you that is a liar. It is 100% cross platform for web backends though. There is nothing you can do in windows that you can't in Linux and VSCode has better support for ASP.NET development than for Go development for example. You can turn VSCode into an IDE or just use the dotnet CLI to build a backend. There are old remains of the .NET framework (not .NET Core) which are still Windows only but they're deprecated and they all have a better cross platform alternative. For example, IIIS (load balancer / reverse proxy) was Windows only but now we have YARP (api gateway / load balancing / reverse-proxying) that is more performant (than IIS, Nginx and Apache altogether), more flexible, and works with all platforms and plugs with all languages.

>>90762082
No, aside from the official doc i don't like MS content. I think Stackoverflow has asp.net as the backend framework with the most questions and answers so you will find what you need there. I'm going to share with you some content creators who will make your life easier.

> Patrick God
if you're a beginner in backends what you seem to be
> Nick Chapsas
for keeping you up to date and for giving you useful performance tips including how to handle concurrency and paralelism in dotnet, you might want to leave it for later though since you're a beginner
> CodeOpinion
If you struggle about system design concerns and how to define the architecture of your backend (assuming it's complex)

As for libraries, most of them are already part of the dotnet runtime but you might want to check:
> Entity Framework Core (EF Core)
It's the official dotnet ORM relying on high lever constructs (LINQ). It's SQL Injection safe as long as you don't write raw SQL code but it's easy to write non performant code with EF if you don't know what you're doing

> Dapper
A micro-orm that lets you write your SQL code and call stored procedures

> Identity Framework
It has everything you need to handle authentication, authorization, security, tokenization, jwt generation, role creation, multi-tenancy (Teddy Smith has a great free course on this and other beginner friendly dotnet courses).

> Throw
A useful lightweight library to implement guard clauses in a clean way (without if statement boilerplate)

> Masstransit or Mediator library
That's for later, when you start to learn about in process and out of process messaging (kafka and rabbitmq)

Roadmap
> Learn how to setup a simple dotnet web api, if you're a retard this course is for you:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_8nLSsK5NDo&list=PL82C6-O4XrHdiS10BLh23x71ve9mQCln0

> Learn Domain Driven Design and Clean Architecture

> Learn Identity Framework (optional) or use a third party SSO library

> Learn abt Microservices and API Gateways

posts.com:
>>90764493
If you want to keep the costs high for a small project deployment i think Vultr is the cheapest reliable cloud provider.

As for auth good practices, there are many:
> hash and salt the password
Never store the passwords in plaintext, using a hashing function to hash the password, and to avoid rainbow table reverse hashing add a salt. You will store the passwordhash and the passwordsalt in your DB.

> Hide your secrets and keys in a secure location and refresh time from time to time
Use a key vault or store them in an environment variable or use a third party key management service.

> Use HTTP only JWT tokens
When a user is authenticated, you send him a JWT token which contains claims (such as his id, email address, permissions, roles, his tenantid). This token will go through the headers but will be an HTTP-Only cookie, which means it can't be read by the client through the dev console or by any other mean and the communication will be encrypted through SSL (or even better, through http3).

> Use the Token to implement authorization
When a user is authenticated, that doesn't mean that he has access to all the routes of your app, some routes might be guarded and only accessible to users who match a certain clause. Depending on your type of backend (monolith or microservices) you will use either a symmetric encryption or assymetric encryption (with a private key for the auth microservice and a public key for the other services). What happens is that a middleware code is executed on each request to a guarded route. The code checks if there's a valid JWT and if the JWT contains the claim (could be a user role for example).

> Rely on an SSO provider
Don't want to take care of AuthN? and AuthZ? Well then just use the Google, Github, Facebook or Microsoft Single Sign On auth services.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90764493
Also, the list of advises i gave you about auth isn't exhaustive. You can for example:

> verify unique identifiers
I don't mean the user ID but unique identifiers like an email address and a phone number. I'm not talking about the regex check to see if it complies with the RFC rules about what makes an email address valid for example. I'm talking about:

1/ making sure it's unique against your db (if you have many services you might want to make them unique for a single service or within the scope of a single tenant depending on the design of your app)

2/ Making sure the user owns the email address or the phone (through a verification email or an sms)

> Add 2factor authentication
If you want a service that needs a higher level of security you can implement 2factor auth by forcing the user to enter an sms sent on his personal phone number to sign on.

> add yubikey auth
if you want to go full schizo you can add another layer of security by forcing the user to enter a yubikey in his device to access some guarded endpoints (mostly used in internal webapps to secure access and mostly to make people accountable in case of data breach of the company's data).

I use this:
import { CookieService } from 'ngx-cookie-service'

It's angular's cookies, for the front.
I have no idea if the user can read them or not, but the front end sure can.
About encryption, I plan on using this:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nt0qLz7ExEE
No JWT since I honestly have no idea how to go at it.

My idea is the following:
. fr sends login credentials
. be recives credentials
. . checks if they're right
. . if they're right it creates a new row in the sessions table with the folloing info:
. . . sessionId, userId, creationDate, token
. . inside the token you'll find, encrypted, the session ide, the user id and the creationDate
. back end sends this token to the front end
. front end saves this token inside one of the cookies mentioned earlyer
. from now on, front end will provide the token when requesting a guarded route (guarded in the front end, angular)
. the back end will receive the token, check against the sessions table and if it is found it'll check user id and check for roles/permissions to proceed with guarded admin route (for example)
.

Those parentheses allow the function to be anonymously defined without a variable declaration, e.g. 

(() => { ... })


if you appended "()" to the end, it can be immediately invoked, e.g.

const isAdmin = (() => {
  if (user.roles.includes("admin")) {
    return true;
  }
  if (process.env.NODE_ENV === "development") {
    return true;
  }
  return false;
})();

console.log(isAdmin);

If you don't make your cookies http-only it means that someone on the frontend can read them and access the data you are sending and it might be sensitive. An http-only header is not accessible by the end user. There are many dangers to making your access cookie readable from the frontend.

Examples
> a third party malicious actor can access it through XSS (cross site scripting). In some sites, simple things such as a userId can be used maliciously.

It seems like JWTs are a perfect solution to your issue. I don't understand why you don't use them.

There's another issue. If i can read your auth cookie and if there's no encrypted signature which ensures the origin of the issuer i can easily use Postman or cURL to send a request to one of your "guarded" routes using the data i acquired from an XSS attack. It gets even worse if your UserIDs are ints or bigints that auto-increment instead of UUIDs (or Ulids) since i can just increment or decrement the Id in the cURL request to access the private data of a different user.

It seems like JWTs are a perfect solution for the problems you mentioned but even the auth scheme you use must have an encryption signature implementation and must allow you to use httpOnly headers, you just have to search how to add it.

>JS is pretty damn good at scaling across multiple machines.
That statement is misleading and confusion. JS is not "good" at scaling across multiple machines. It's only way of scaling IS through multiple machines. Good at scaling across multiple machines compared to what? To Java, C# and Go? No. Compared to Python or Ruby? Yeah, i agree.

> It has threading in web workers.
Threading in JS is expensive and comes with a lot of quirks. Conventional threading (using OS threads) is expensive enough in and of itself and programming languages that try to solve the issues of concurrency for a web backend are exploring alternatives such as Coroutines, Fibers, Green/Virtual threads and runtime/compiler managed thread pools. Java is working on the project loom, Dotnet has the Task Parallel Library and are considering introducing green threads into the CLR, Go has its lightweight Goroutines.

> Does that make JS bad for web backends?
A definitive no. You can use it for starting your project, and since you're splitting it into services / modules, the cost of refactoring shouldn't be high (especially if you do clean architecture or just ddd). It's also good as part of larger systems for some parts of the infrastructure. Actually i never claimed it was bad, it's just not as fit/good for web backends as C#, Java and Go purely in terms of performance. In terms of ease of use, i get that it's more straightforward than Go but i see no advantage in using Node.js over Dotnet. The latter might even be easier.

>>90767451
gRPC can also be used for server to client interactions just like how websockets can be used for server to client communication and for gateway to services communication (so server to server).

The performance difference of gRPC vs websockets is minimal and gRPC might even become faster if it migrates to the QUIC protocol. I find gRPC more useful for backend to client communication over service to service communication.

When you have multiple microservices communicating between each other, you want to reduce coupling and you want to avoid having a spider's net of intercoms. A message queue or event bus like RabbitMQ or Kafka that sits in the middle is better for this kind of architecture. Each service is agnostic of the other services and only publishes messages to say RabbitMQ and the services that need this message consume it from there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90768402
Twitter currently uses C++, Java and Scala for their backends as well as some old codebases written in RoR. Facebook is mostly C++ and PHP/Hack. Their applications are written as microservices which sit behind api gateways. To access the feed microservice (for example), the call goes to the api gateway of your region (say western europe) which routes it to one of the many instances of the feed api (generaly the one with the better health checks, lower cpu and ram usage). That's how they handle things on the application layer at scale. On the database layer, for facebook for example, they have 1000 MySQL databases and 1000 Memcache caches. They rely heavily on caching to serve frequently requested data in with near 0 latency. Their MySQL implementation is distributed through sharding. For the database layer, since a social media typically has many times more reads than writes, they use multiple read databases for one write database.

Now this is how things are handled at Facebook which processes billions of requests per second and stores trillions of objects in its databases.
Reddit is another story. Reddit is a simple monolith on the application layer.

You could use Node.TS if you want. I would've recommended one of these: Java - .NET - Go but Node works too. What you need to think about is how you will design your social network to avoid high maintenance cost and keep things modular. If you're making a monolith learn how to design a modular monolith and how to define clear boundaries between your modules. If you're expecting fast growth and decent traffic within a year put your backend infrastructure (either monolithic or microservices) behind an api gateway so you can balance the load across multiple instances of your api in case of high traffic and use something like Redis or Memcache for storing frequently used data in RAM.

For the db you can use anything from PostgreSQL to MongoDB or Cassandra. They would all work.

For medias you need a CDN.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90769119
I am building a suite of microservices with performance and scalability in mind and yes, your guess was write, i've read a facebook document about how they approached scaling their infrastructure by running 1000 servers of memcache (the largest existing memcached implementation) and how they created and then mostly dropped cassandra to focus only on mysql with myrocksdb.

I personnaly have a bias towards dotnet because it ranks better than the others on three features i value a lot. It's the most robust (offers more built-in constructs and provides lower margin for error or to shoot yourself in the foot), it's the easiest to use to build anything complex. It's the one that offers the fastest response time.
Go is better in many ways though. It's more verbose and slightly less fast for response time than dotnet but it comes with a more significant memory usage advantage and with a slightly better concurrency model. Java feels more chaotic and less user friendly but it has a the largest existing ecosystem of libraries for backend dev.

I think the best way to figure out what to use is to think about a very simple prototype project and implement it in the three languages and go with the one that suits you the most. They're all capable of handling the kind of systems you want to build at scale. You could also do it in Node if you want.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90775214
There are many ways to think about your problem, here are the three main aspects you need to think about:
> Content Delivery (static pages, images, videos)
> Application Layer (web servers)
> Persistence Layer (db and cache)

I will try to provide solutions for each of these in that order (from easiest to solve to hardest).

> Content Delivery
If you are not already using a CDN for delivering content such as images, files, videos and static pages i suggest that you start doing so now. You will increase the overall loading speed and make this data accessible from across the globe with minimal latency. The CDN handles that for you. But you have to make sure that your CDN actually replicates data and has servers all across the globe and not just in Singapore.


> Application layer
The idea is to operate multiple API gateways that are spread across different regions (the regions where you have significant traffic of course). Traffic from a given region will be directed its assigned API Gateway which will balance the load across multiple instances of your service depending on the health checks of each regional server.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90775214
> Persistence Layer
This is where everything gets tricky because we are talking about data storage and access across multiple regions. You could use a globally distributed database like CosmosDB which supports databases such as Postgres, Cassandra and Mongo. CosmosDB would guarantee global availability and data replication across a cluster but you could also do it on your own and databases like CosmosDB are costly to operate.

You are already in the right direction. You should make a database cluster with a node per region and replicate data across your different nodes so that a user moving from a region to another will access a replica of his data locally. You don't necessarily have to replicate everything. You could replicate the authentication data only for example and whenever a cache the data you will need for said user on login if said user belongs to a region and connects from another one. That way you will have a near 0 latency right after login.

>Just adding read replicas and keep one master db in one of the regions will probably not be enough, as we often need to do writes.
For most types of applications, reads are always more expensive and more recurrent than writes. If you don't have frequent writes you could accept some level of network latency. If you want to eliminate it, here's what you want to do:
create a temporary database for writes that should be redirected to another region or even better, make them go through an event bus or a message queue. The write will be validated once it is in the temporary storage and the query will be fast. Then the event will be consumed by the appropriate service, in the appropriate region and stored in the right db.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90775214
Sorry, i just noticed how poorly written the last part of my explanation was (about making the persistence layer globally available): >>90776004

So i'll make things easier to understand. You can split the explanation in two parts, distributing reads and write access to make up for network latency.

1/ DISTRIBUTING READS GLOBALLY
You can use two different strategies to approach this problem

> 1st strategy: sharding auth data + caching on demand
Here you want to replicate auth data accross your different regions so that a user that belongs to region A and finds itself in region B can access a replica of his data locally with minimal latency. When the user from region A authenticates in a new region, an event is fired. His data, or the parts of his data that he will most likely need to use will be sent through a message and stored on a temporary cache in region B (you can use memcache or redis for that), that way, he can access his data with near 0 latency during his session or his future sessions (depending on the duration of your cache).

> 2nd strategy: Full sharding
Here you want to replicate all the data that is suspected to be used by a user in each region so that you don't have to fire an event on login or rely on caching but have it available in the persistence data store everywhere. It's more costly but easier to implement

2/ DISTRIBUTING WRITES GLOBALLY
Here the solution is easier to implement. As i said earlier, you could just send writes to the database of the assigned region of the user but if you have frequent writes you might want to implement things differently.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90776591
> If you have full sharding
If the data is replicated across all region, then a write will be stored locally then replicated across the different regions and that's it.

> If you rely on partial sharding (of auth data) and on caching responses
In that case a write will need to be stored on the assigned region of the user. You can do it through messaging using Kafka or RabbitMQ or even Redis. If a user from region A writes something in region B, you can validate the command when it's passed onto the message queue or in the temporary local store and let him carry on with his work. The data is then consumed by one of the instances of your service in his local region and persisted to his regional database. That way, the network latency for writes reaches a near 0.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90776605
If you don't want to fully replicate your data across regions then you can pass the user's region in the authentication token and force the user to start a new session when he finds himself in a new region. Only the authentication data needed will be replicated (userId, pass, email, pseudonym, assignedRegion). As i said, on auth, the personal user data will be sent through messaging to a local cache after the auth is done (through an event). If there's data that is shared by all your users globally you might want to replicate it across multiple regions to make it globally accessible.

I need to have more insight on the type of application you have and your tech stack to give you a better insight. Are you sure that the latency your users are experience is a network latency? It's most likely due to something else.

Also, if you distribute the application layer globally and don't do anything about the persistence layer, you will create more latency than having everything in a single region. Why? Because instead of sending a request from europe that will go to your webserver in Singapore (which will query the data from a DB in the same datacenter as the webserver), what you are doing is sending the request from Rome to your regional webserver in London which will then query it from your database in Singapore. If you want to make your app globally distributed, you need to distribute every layer of your application. Your application response time is only as fast as its slowest node.

As i said earlier if there's data that is shared by all your users you can just replicate it across your different regions and alter it globally on write.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90776706
>Any specific links or guides that goes in more detail how to setup a defer/lazy write to the DB?
It depends on the mechanism you choose. If you choose to replicate all your data globally you will just have to write it globally, if you want to use an event-based mechanism then it's just basic understanding of redis or amazon SQS and basic knowledge of asynchronous messaging. The steps are simple:
1/ user from region A writes in region B
2/ server finds in the headers (jwt token) that the user is not from region B and fires an event to amazon SQS to publish the data to the local node of the message queue instead of storing it in the local db
3/ server from region A consumes the data from region B and stores it in the local db

The user's write is confirmed once it's in the message queue and the next steps are handled after command confirmation.

posts.com:
>>90776706
Also, you might want to optimize the way you store your data. For example, if you use UUIDs and store thing as strings it will take 37 bytes per UUID, but if you use a more efficient data type (eg. the uuid data type in postgres) it will take 16 bytes per UUID. Another example is with indexing. If you don't index your lookup data it will not be sorted efficiently. An indexed string of text for example will be sorted in alphabetical order and that can reduce the time to process a read massively. If you have data that needs to be unique, beware of checking its uniqueness on the application layer through counts. Avoid counts at all costs because they are expensive and involve iterating through a column from a to z even if the data you want to access is already found. You can use a unique index or just use a different mechanism than count(*), like SELECT EXISTS (with LIMIT 1). Are you loading the data you need to alter on update on the application layer or are you using batch/bulk updates? That might be one reason among many for your response time latency.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90751539
>Just the standards

So, for basic effects, the industry standards are:

>Waves (the boomer choice as they were already in the plugin game 30 years ago, but the gigantic number of plugins can be overwhelming for a beginner)
>FabFilter (the modern choice, just a few plugins with zero bloat and a neat interface, used by everyone, can never go wrong with it)
>iZotope (more used for special applications like mastering, audio restoration…)
>for reverb, Valhalla (affordable + no bullshit interface + sounds amazing)

And that’s it. So it would make sense for you to go with the FabFilter bundle + maybe a Valhalla reverb (ValhallaRoom or ValhallaVintageVerb) or the old Altiverb if you like it better. People can suggest 5,000 other plugins that are cheaper, marginally better or whatever like ToneBoosters, Plugin Alliance, DMG Audio and so on, but these are the ubiquitous ones. Walk into any studio in the world and the engineer will likely have Waves and/or FabFilter plugins. Need tutorials or tips? YouTube is full of videos showcasing these plugins, etc.

Also I’d rather rely on these third-party plugins than on FL Studio ones for standard effects (the latter are okay and serviceable, but not great like, say, FabFilter Pro-Q or ValhallaRoom).

Why do you want another DAW? It’s usually best to stick with what you know. I can understand that you want a completely fresh approach after a break though. I did the same myself. As a previous FL Studio user who was back into music-making, this was my path:

>Reaper (felt miserable as you explained)
>Studio One (very neat and pleasant to use, but the bundled content is kinda meh)
>Logic Pro, which I still use now (less snappy to use than Studio One, but having god-tier stock sounds and plugins, a beautiful UI, countless forum topics and videos covering every single question you could have, deep options with MIDI or the Environment… makes it an even better and more productive experience overall)

I tried FL Studio again after that, but wouldn’t trade Logic or even Studio One for it nowadays.

Also, Ableton Live is the most popular DAW today, and everyone should try it, but it did nothing for me so I can’t recommend it personally.

>>90774833
I have found it very helpful to ignore the Pattern Sequencer completely when creating a song on the timeline. That means loading all your instruments from the playlist (which will automatically assign a track to the mixer and creates a pattern named after the instrument). By creating all new clips in the timeline you are able to dynamically change pattern sizes based on how you resize them in the playlist.

The pattern sequencer is good to work in when you are specifically creating patterns that you might use for live performance or something like that. Once I stopped thinking about the pattern sequencer and started working almost exclusively in the playlist everything clicked. Hope this makes sense.

Highly recommend Godot and gdscript, with gdnative you can write modules for your game if you need something extra performant.

>>90767295
>random public functions
no functions/methods should be "random"
in OOP languages like Java, you need to learn to apply context to behavior
behavior always has some kind of subject

for example, you might think a "max()" function shouldn't belong to nothing
but the subject of "max()" is always some kind of collection of items
so in OOP you would have some kind of "comparable" collection with a "max()" method that would compare its elements to each other and return the one that's higher than any other

>Like if I have a gui with different windows, and there's a button in each one that takes you back to the main menu. Do I really need to copy and paste the same returntomainmenu function in each class?
already your setup seems wrong and will cause you troubles in the long run

if you had a Window class that just composes WindowElements such as buttons, and a ReturnToMainMenuButton class that implements a WindowElement interface, you could just add a ReturnToMainMenuButton object to each window

>>90762526
The creative process is intensely derivative, it's not uncommon for inventions and ideas to be put out within incredibly short timespans that are very similar but have been created independently. Copyright has only served to make it more so by incentivizing companies to pump out derivative products to no end and influencing the collective pool of ideas people draw on.
Consider that the ability to trivially replicate, market and distribute intellectual goods has made drastic strides in contrast to printing press days and that it would have been expected for legislation that exists to allow for creators to make their full profit off of a work (after originally being censorship tool) to have been reduced in duration and scope in response to that. Instead the duration has been increased to keep major businesses in market since it's a significant weapon to wield against smaller businesses and individuals who can't take the legal fees and also prevents people from getting big off public domain work like the big players did.
I'm not sure whether the frivolously extended duration of copyright or the frivolous granting of patents is the worse crime of IP.

posts.name: d0_0b
posts.com:
>>90776193
you will never have to decompile anything in programming, its only used for cracking, gamehacking and similar tasks. to crack a program youll want to understand how it does its license checks and whatnot. for gamehacking youll want to understand how the game works to abuse its mechanics and similar. so yeah people decompiling your code can be a problem if youre selling something or whatever.

but no one will actually "hide" their code like that, because first and foremost of all, it just breaks the pseudo code generation on 1 (one) disassembler. you can probably fix it with a python plug for said disassembler, and even if you cant, people can still read the assembly itself, its just ever so slightly more tedious

the way people protect themselves from their code being decompiled is by using packers (look into themida or vmprotect). these things will remove/hide info, scramble your code, maybe encrypt it and more. themida for example, can turn your code into its own bytecode which it will then execute in its vm. and you can have a vm in a vm. note that vm doesnt refer to something like virtualbox or vmware, its virtual machine in the same way as JVM, lua vm, or python vm.
i once had my program encapsuled with 6 (six!) vms, the performance was utter shit but id like to see someone try to fully RE that.

i mean yeah its possible, but youd need to dedicate your day life to it for quite a period of time. its very tedious.

ok so heres an example: gamed and their anticheats. easy anticheat for example, to avoid being reverse engineered, doesnt give you its binaries. instead theyre streamed over the internet in the form of bytecode and only kept in memory to make it harder to capture the code and reverse engineer it. vac also streams its binaries over the internet and doesnt store them on your disk, though in contrast to EAC, it streams entire (protected) modules, not just pieces of bytecode.

sorry for the chaotic way of writing, i hope you learned something

>>90734525
Hifi audio as a hobby/interest is already a niche. This general dies so often because nobody has anything to talk about. There's no creativity in the posts, and it often devolves into brand wars.A Speakers would even be less active, more so because of the setup they require in order to maximize performance. Factor in the costs of having a proper treated space wherein you can listen in peace and the cost of good speakers and you have a recipe for an even more niche interest. Speakers are generally more in line with boomers, because they have the money to burn and are also far more open to snakeoil shit. You'll hear anons talk about Genelecs as an accessible brand for the endgame audio setups they can afford, but that's barely scratching the surface. Personally, with all that in mind, why would anyone invest minimally, relatively speaking in speakers when you can have a 3-5k Headphone setup that's already overkill, but you and anybody else would very likely be satisfied unless you are chasing after the dragon and keep wanting to upgrade past that.

IEM is the future of the hobby, because it's accessible.

>>90741449
I really wish people would stop considering Crinacle as some type of authority, this was a simple article to write and he still got it wrong.
>Which is ironic, because many “gaming headphones” tend to be tuned rather bass-heavy, and so isn’t really competitive in this regard. You wouldn’t want footsteps and gunshots drowned out every time an explosion happens, or if a vehicle is idling nearby.
Literally everything he mentions peak in bass with the exception of small-caliber gunshots and they're the main audio cues competitive players are using in most games. Game developers mix their audio for v-shape tuning which will be used by the vast majority of the players.
>In almost every case, an open-backed headphone (a headphone that does not block out any outside noise) will be the better than a closed-back headphone for staging and imaging ability. Open-backs typically sound wider with more pin-point imaging, of course assuming it is being used in a quiet environment. Which, again, is ironic as most “gaming headphones” are closed-back.
It should be assumed that most gaymers will be next to a loud gaming PC and they'll have reduced dynamic range without good noise isolation, decreasing immersion. He implies that muh soundstage is useful for spatial cues when it's not, has he never tried playing a game with good IEMs? Imagining is quantifiable, issues like channel imbalance will affect localization accuracy.
>For these people, the qualities that make a headphone “competitively advantageous” and “immersive” are at odds with one another
Just false.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
been using this thing for a month
a chink eink ui bolted on top an android 11 ("library" is literary hacked into the launcher, setting up a wallpaper behind icon grid is intentionally broken to show plain white)
can install anything from fdroid
don't expect something like lineage to ever run on this due to being obscure and the proprietary drivers
5 responsiveness/resolution modes from crisp and slow to ghosting & dithered and less slow
normal android settings menu and file manager hidden but can be accessed from a custom launcher
to "opt out" of some of the spying you need to access those hidden normal android settings
most settings are accessible in the chink ui though
wonky default combination and multiple options of virtual navigation buttons and gestures, takes couple of weeks of tweaking settings to get truly comfortable with
default document reader program is very good, can write in pdfs with the pen (instant feedback), also takes time to get used to and tweak
clock is never right (unless connected to internet) and alarm is unusable due to the hardcore power-saving
cold and warm backlight whose intensities can be mixed
can read in bright sun without the backlight (awesome)
if you want to view the opened documents in the task switcher you must open them from the stock "library" app, which does not show in other launchers, so you are basically stuck with the default chinky launcher
being able to snap the and firmly hold pen on the edge of the device is underrated
the plain cover that comes with the device is crap because it doesn't snap together when opened, just flaps about unless you hold it
the more expensive keyboard cover is good at being a cover and snaps together when opened, also provides slight corner protection. keyboard connects via magnetic 5pin apple-charger looking connector instead of bt, doesn't require a battery.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualisation. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

>>90765562
>Any tipps on getting started with docker?
Install docker, install docker-compose, find something developed by someone that you want to run, make it work. Most of the time you'll be able to find a pre-built docker-compose file for it, but learn what all the parts do.
>Just looked into it, and the first thing i read was that pihole does not work propperly as a container. Should i just keep that on the n2?
I don't really like pihole, I always found it flaky no matter what I ran it on. It does work in a container though, but you probably don't want to run its DHCP bits because of the way docker networking works.
I use NextDNS.io to accomplish the same thing, and it works on my phone remotely without having to do any funky networking stuff to avoid having an open DNS resolver on the net.

>Yes, a database io profile will also do much the same, but we're not talking about the same level of $$ spend on hardware and software solutions to minimize that issue. If you're putting a database on a RAIDZ of spinning drives you're a retard who gets what they deserve.

>Most of these anons are wanting to access media, which is "start at the begging, and read everything until the end" which will be fastest in a non-fragmented mode.
"Fastest" is entirely irrelevant when the box can pull data off the array faster than it can put it on the network.

>>90776705
If all you want is a writing computer, you should get the attached machine instead of a ThinkPad. It is a lot more mobile than a laptop and runs on 18650 batteries which are user swappable with a little door like how double As used to go in a Gameboy. The double wide screen means you can have Latex and your compiled PDF up and maximized at the same time, so you get a 2 monitor workflow out of it. You also won't have to waste a bunch of money buying """""ergonomic""""" cope office equipment that serves no good purpose and clutters your house, because it is a handheld and you can operate it standing/walking. It has a headphone jack so you can use mp3s while you write. You also don't need any peripherals to use it. They designed it using tricks from Gundam model kits so it comes in a tray with molded plastic parts and you snap them out and assemble the computer. It doesn't require any tools to do. You turn each of those black knobs a half turn or so and the whole machine can be popped apart to access the hardware if you need to.

If you go this road, I recommend getting whatever core compiles your LaTeX documents quickest, since that has a direct impact on how productive your time using the computer is.

>>90763313
In the Windows 8 case, due to changes deep down in the storage stack (the new Storage API is just the tip of the iceberg, trust me), we found out a couple of filter drivers we'd written were doing... naughty things. Since the documentation on drivers is already pretty threadbare, and we were having trouble getting someone from the Storage team to talk to us, the higher-ups decided the best way to do it was sign the NDA and get a look, ironically.
Funnily enough, I don't quite recall why I was sent to look at the 10 source (we actually scheduled before the 1507 RTM, but I didn't go to Redmond until after) - some interoperability issue is all I recall.

For notes I usually split the page into 2 columns. The main notes go in the larger right column, while diagrams and important equations go in the left. If I’m looking for something in my notes I skim the left column to find what I’m broadly looking for and then read the details on the right.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90765057
Similar, but Cornell notes are mainly used for humanities, and i mainly take notes for sciences. Instead of filling in the left column after I’m done, I usually start each topic with a diagram illustrating it in the left column, and then explain in detail in the right column. Diagrams are very important to make notes easy to find and understand, so I usually base my detailed notes in the right column on the corresponding diagram.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90759788
As I said, it's all 3 for 6$ deals, so everything cost effectively 2$ each.
1. Aux Bluetooth receiver - haven't tested it yet, but it looks fine. Buttons feels suprisingly satisfying. MicroUSB cable is ultra short, which was to be expected. Pretty good for the price.
2. 100 chinese bandaids. Might give me band-aids. Time will tell.
3. A very nice little pouch. Comes well packaged with one main compartment and one outer compartment that stretches to fit larger items. Attaches to a belt or molle system. Comes with a carabiner and foam inside so it keeps its form in transport, pleasantly surprised by the quality. Buckle is cheap plastic though. I'd have preferred it without the "sport" on it, but very happy for 2$.
4. Plush shark. I have since learned that plush sharks are a lbtq thing, but whatever. It's cute and it was 2$. Can't complain.
5. Wine stoppers, 2 pcs. Got them as gifts, they should do the job. Enough to keep flies out at least.
6. Folding rubber band gun with rubber bands. The front attachment hook for the rubber bands isn't big enough, so you can't load more than 4 bands at once into the revolver, but other than that it's nice. Might get a second as a gift so I can shoot a friend whenever we meet each other.
7. Chinese lego set. Not sure yet if it'll be a gift or if I will build it myself. If I do, I will report back.
8. Metal hooks. They do what they say, no complaints here.
9. 2m LED strip with motion sensor. I hope the motion sensor works well, but I can't test it at the moment.
10. 5 of those "eternal pencil leads". No idea how well they will work, I hope it's not a normal pencil lead or else it'll be real annoying to sharpen once it wears off.
11. A plant sprayer that attaches to PET bottles. Looks like it'll work and will be great help for the upcoming spring in the garden. Very nice.
(cont)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90760165
(cont)
12. "multitool". It's very small, but that was to be expected. The knife on it is short and dull as shit, but nothing that a few minutes on a sharpening stone couldn't fix. It does have springs that make using the plier part more enjoyable. Since it's so small it could be a nice thing to carry with you when space and weight are at a premium. I do not have too high hopes for the carbon content of the steel, probably going to be very soft and dull quickly.
13. USB-C (M) to MicroUSB (F), USB-A (M) to USB-C(F) and USB-C(M) to USB-A(F) adapters. All advertised as "USB 3.0" and surprisingly the USB ports do have the appropriate amount of pins. Did not expect that. Quite handy.
14. Electronics organizer. Quite a lot bigger than I expected, but I like it. A neon green inside that makes you retinas bleed, but good sectioning.
15. A generic x-acto knife with replacement blades. Very nice.

Overall, very happy with the stuff. Not a single item in there that feels super cheaply made or like it would work badly.

But that may also be because it's ages and I use more force now or some shit. All the parts except that piston feel like normal generic lego parts, no weird pieces here. I also wouldn't be surprised if they were compatible with lego. I don't have any to compare, but they seem the same size that lego used to be. Overall, mabe 90% of the way to real lego. In a side by side I may be able to tell it's a copy, but without that reference it's really hard to tell. Also the parts being a bit lighter and probably made from another plastic did not impact the assembly part at all in terms of feel.

What's your setup? I watched couple videos, read some things here and there but they all do different things which is reasonable. What's the proper way to do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
you download a latex distribution and get cracking. miktex and tex live are the two popular ones. there's also overleaf but you said no cloud so not overleaf. miktex came with an editor that did live previews, so you typed in the LHS of your screen and saw what it did in the RHS, which I thought was neat.

for my lecture notes in uni I literally had one .tex file per course that I typed in. term project was more complex, had one file per chapter which I \input together in a top level document. also, use bibtex to manage references.

learning latex has one downside. in the future, whenever you use a boomer, normie, or retard word processor like word or google docs you'll feel dirty and be really annoyed at how crap those apps are. have you tried maintaining an index in Word or even having nested section numbering?

>>90772978
Land of LISP and Design Patterns are both meme-tier garbage.

Land of LISP is garbage because it isn't good at teaching LISP or teaching game development.

Design Patterns is a garbage cope book that only exists because the advantages of OOP break down at scale. Instead of using OOP design patterns and generating a tremendous amount of boilerplate code to make something sort of work, change to a paradigm more suited for your task. Design Patterns were born out of a corporate version of the sunk costs fallacy and should almost always just be rejected out of hand as not being a serious solution to a problem.

Code Complete is also garbage. It only really has some historical interest if you want to know what Microsoft developers were doing 30 years ago.

You can do really advanced queries with SQL in a standardized manner while having a metric shitton of data. There are also noSQL DBs such as MongoDB, these are quite different (Mongo stores it like a bunch of JSONs with some voodoo indexing magic attached)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90758864
Generally in "Devops land" (and well IT Infrastructure in general) is that you don't want to write to local data stores if you need to persist the data.

Secondly, the days of pure monolithic solutions where you install databases locally on the application is also not the right choice (you should be utilizing an external database)

Like if its a Config file, local data store is fine, but if you are storing persistant data use SQL/noSQL DB solutions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90761252
Real answer because for some reason the NEETs in this general somehow think flying planes is easy: at least in my country you do the equivalent of an engineering degree on top of your actual flight training. After 4 years of this you start as a copilot making about 100k, then keep doing training and tests while you build experience. You need to maintain thousands of hours of flight time every year to stay licensed. If you fail a test at any time you scrub out. After 5 YoE or so you can do the test to become a captain and start making bank, but if you fail you scrub out. No second chance, you are a copilot forever unless you quit and go to an LCC. Also if you fail a monthly health check you’re grounded until you get better. That means a chronic ear infection can essentially end your career because you don’t book enough flight time to stay current. The reason for this is that there’s so many rules to flying that if you stop doing it for a few months you will fuck up, and if you fuck up people die.

tldr pilots are a lot more deserving of the title “engineer” than software devs are, and that’s why good ones make more money than you (and the bad ones scrub out).

This thread is for the discussion of in-ear monitors and portable music players.

/iemg/ Guide and Hall of Fame:
• https://hackmd.io/@AyPeeEye/S1sNUVosu
• 7Hz Salnotes Zero (boosted neutral) - $20
• Tangzu Wan'er S.G (mild V) - $20
• QKZ x HBB (big bass) - $20
• Tinhifi C3 (mild U) - $50
• Moondrop Aria Snow Edition (warm neutral) - $80
• [The one that you are using] - $???

/earbuds/ Hall of Fame:
• https://hackmd.io/@AyPeeEye/S1sNUVosu#Hall-of-Fame1

/pmpg/ Guide and Hall of Fame:
• https://azalush5.hatenablog.com/entry/2022/01/dap-comparison-2022-01
• Your phone
• HiBy R3 Pro Saber 2022 - $210
• Sony NW-A55 + MrWalkman firmware - ~$200 used

/USB/BT DAC/ Hall of Fame:
• OpenHeart CX31993 (budget functional) - $10
• Venture Electronics Abigail (bundle w/ Monk Plus earbuds) - $15
• Moondrop Dawn (3.5 or 4.4) - $70
• Tanchjim Space (dual 3.5 and 4.4 + hardware volume) - $90
• Qudelix 5K (dual 3.5 and 2.5 + Bluetooth) - $110

/TWS/ Hall of Fame:
• https://www.scarbir.com/truewireless
• Samsung Galaxy Buds Pro 2 - $230
• Apple AirPods Pro 2 - $250

• Why use a PMP instead of a phone?
>Better DAC/amp
>More output power so it can drive higher impedance headphones
>Smaller sizes than phones for activities like exercise
>Physical buttons
>Headphone jacks
>Some people can't use smartphone at work/use dumbphones

• How to request advice:
>Budget
>Source (phone or PMP)
>Location
>Kind (in-ear or earbuds)
>Sound signature (or genres you like, important!)
>Past gear and your thoughts on them (important!)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90743751
Xelastec are not known for their durability at all but YMMV. They are prone to folding (especially if they are too big for you) which can be somewhat remedied by picking smaller size which may or may not be too small for a proper seal.
Regular silicone tips last forever and are easy to maintain.
If you want foam look into hybrids (basically foam with silicone on top).
Xelastec are a middle ground. Not as durable as silicone but more durable than foam if you can find the right size (big enough to seal but not big enough to fold).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
TKZK Ouranos ($55) vs. Tripowin x HBB Olina SE ($99)

Build: Pseudocustom resin > metal shell. Ouranos is lightweight and sits nicely in-ear. Olina SE fairs worse with it's non-custom, generic oblong shell that feels loose and cumbersome. Ouranos wins.

Stock accessories: I like the functionality of Olina SE cable: it is lightweight, memory-resistant, and just works, but aesthetically sucks. Olina SE stock tips are bad. Ouranos sleek 2-core is relatively uncommon so nice to see, but it's not well-behaved (holds bends & tangles). Ouranos tips are typical Tinhifi/TKZK, a nice set of both regular & wider bore tips that I do like. No winner, both subpar packages.

Sound: Same DAC & cable, straight from weeks of Olina SE listening to the Ouranos. Ouranos is harder-than-average to drive, nothing crazy.

Bass: Ouranos reaches deeper into sub bass. Plays with a heavier weight than Olina SE. Olina SE retains advantage of supernatural speed in the low-end, doesn't ever linger, plays and then decays.

Mids: Olina SE has the more correct mids, in line with expected neutral. Ouranos is more U-shaped. Pro is nice macro contrast between bass, mids, and treble, more exciting listen. Con is non-linear mids, slight recess.

Treble: Ouranos treble tuning is very good. Enhanced vocals, but still smooth, resistant to sibilance, ending with a natural rolloff. Olina SE presents as brighter, clearer, and with more extension. Olina SE excels at delivering on female vocals and treble detail being center-stage. Olina SE is superior at layering and separation, Ouranos is a more cohesive sound.

If you like: treble detail, bright, neutral, less bass, then choose Olina SE.
If you like: warm/smooth listen, balanced U-shape, a little more rumble/slam, then choose Ouranos.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90775458
I don't think there is such a thing, which is okay. Programming languages are meant to abstract away the differences between different computers and it's the compiler's job to perform a high quality translation. You might say "well okay but that just sounds like portable assembly to me" and I would see your point but I think it's unhealthy to conflate C abstractions with reality -- for example a few days ago we had some guy embarrass himself in a thread complaining about some old Linux bug that assumed pointer overflow was defined behaviour, when it was the opposite, claiming the vulnerability was the work of "freetard compilers" when really the spec never says that pointers are numbers of any kind to begin with because computers are more complicated than that, not everything is Intel or ARM. Integer sizes are whatever the vendors want them to be and while int is meant to be the natural word size you'll find more often than not this simply isn't true at all so arithmetic automatically promoting everything to int by default doesn't even work as intended. It's kind of a mess of really high level concepts from the 80s and if you look at how for example the standard denies the possibility of overflow on signed integers, despite targets defining being two's complement or whatever, you can't really call it portable assembly IMO.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90772825
Its funny, because supposed security experts make the same mistake as you, of thinking the method works because the way you generated a password is a secret, and thus the popularity of the method somehow weakens it. The intuition of the method is that most people don't know what a potential password cracker knows about passwords, so they can't possibly defend against that. I was looking at a popular password list the other day, and saw a seemingly random number sequence near the top of the list. So, I looked it up, and it turns out it comes from a television show. Every single person using that password probably thought they were a genius, but in fact they were just a sheep going to slaughter. If you approach password generation in this way, of trying to "one up" crackers, then you may get off fine, or you may do the exact same thing as millions of other people, and make a password that gets guessed immediately. On the other hand, if you assume the cracker knows the exact method used to generate the password, but doesn't have access to the random seed, then you can put a strict lower bound on how long it will take them to crack the password. From there, you can choose exactly how secure you want your password to be.

>>90773643
>For hardware you control, one password for everything.
Or you can have only one password for a dedicated "master" computer: disable the root user and make it so the only way to log in is your init automatically logging you in, and make sudo/doas work without password. This is fine because you will be using full headerless & hashless disk encryption with the keyfile and boot partition on a usb drive.
Use that dedicated master machine to connect to your home wifi and boot your other machines using Netboot. You won't have to enter a password to boot them since you can send the encryption keyfile inside the initramfs you send through netboot.
On the other machines do the same thing: disable root user and have init log you in automatically. Here's the catch: instead of disabling the sudo password, you can use your master machine to authenticate - this is why it's better to use a SBC or a laptop for the master machine, so you can authenticate easily by just pressing one button or key.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90773049
Combining multiple dictionary words into a phrase through brute force is somewhat comparable to individual character brute force attacks. Obviously there are more words than characters, but if you narrow your dictionary down to common words or even pick out certain phrases then you can get results surprisingly quick for 3-4 word passwords. In effect you would need to use some absurdly long (character-wise) passwords or go out of your way to use weird words.
So while you're right that a dictionary attack isn't actually combining words, the kind of brute force attack that they're talking about is still a real threat that makes the xkcd password strategy less convenient.
>>90773409
>>90773491
Random but memorizable gibberish is what I use for my master password. Something like "KipFah42_Vormeen" would be secure and simple to type. The xkcd comic comes from a time when the convenience of easy memorization was worth the length trade-off since you were expected to memorize all of your passwords; now with the master password philosophy I'd argue it's more convenient to go with a shorter gibberish password since it saves you keystrokes while still being secure enough. Long multiword phrases just aren't as convenient when you only have to memorize a single password.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other W10 editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.

Toys like LibreOffice have subtle bugs and features missing that ultimately have catastrophic effects. It's not usable as a Word substitute, because it messes up formatting on anything but the most trivially-designed document. It can't be used as an Excel substitute, because there are enough holes in its VBA parser that macros above a trivial complexity don't work. And so on and so forth.

This is what freetards don't seem to understand: a 90% feature-complete competitor isn't good enough, especially when what you're chasing has been entrenched for decades, and has features that have been implemented for decades. LibreOffice has to have at least feature parity with Office 2007 to have any chance - and it doesn't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90772814
That is not what killed 3dfx.

They stagnated so hard they killed themselves.
They essentially used the same 1998-derived GPU core for every product, and attempted product, from the Voodoo3 and up. The VSA-100 was nothing more than an Avenger core with an RoP out.
The Voodoo5 was nothing but multiple VSA-100s tied to their SLI tech.
3dfx were never going to have a competitive product in time to match Nvidia and ATI, not with the rapidly evolving 3D standards that happened between DirectX 6 and 8.

3dfx started T&L development way, way too late to be competitive. Their contemporaries, instead, had already been planning for T&L capability in future GPUs at least a year before 3dfx shelved Rampage.
The Rampage core wasn't even designed for T&L, and was ditched.
The STB acquisition led to a (more) rapid fiscal failure, but they were already doomed. STB had nothing to do with it really, you're only looking at a symptom of the cause.

3dfx had one single homerun with the Avenger core in their Voodoo2/3 series, but did not look far enough ahead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90709306
>There's no memory management API so you have to have some kind of automatic memory management.
False equivalence. Almost every implementation provides at least a function to free up memory manually (for instance, CCL:GC) and you often have implementation-specific control on the GC, which you can sometimes disable entirely. However, there is nothing mandating that memory management has to happen continuously, as the application runs and without explicit invocation by the programmer.

On a side note, C, at least in the language itself, has no concept of dynamic memory allocation at all, you can only allocate scope-based stack memory. malloc and free are standard library functions, whose behavior is ultimately platform-dependant (malloc could legally always return NULL, possibly to indicate that the underlying platform does not support dynamic allocation).

Plus, the C standard library may not be present at all on some implementations (think about freestanding environments).

Dynamic memory allocation and deallocation are much more platform-dependent than most people believe. A multiplatform programming language can offer at most some guidelines on how it might happen, but it cannot predict implementation-specific details.

>Reference counting is trash, so it effectively mandates GC.
How is this relevant? Who even mentioned reference counting?

>Is it possible to write a lisp in vim and run the file?
yes, you can even do it backwards and run vi/m from the repl and load the resulting file:
;; common lisp
(defparameter *ed-file* nil)

(defun vi (&optional (file *ed-file*) literal)
  (let* ((f (or file *ed-file*))
         (path (if literal file (concatenate 'string f ".lisp"))))
    (cond (f (setf *ed-file* f)
             (run-program "/bin/vi" (list "-l" path) :input t :output t)
             (if literal
                 :ok
                 (load path)))
          (t (error "no file, past or present")))))

(setf *ed-functions* (list #'vi))

;; scheme
(define ed
  (let ((local #f))
    (define (editor . file)
      (set! local (or local (car file)))
      (system* "vi" "-l" local))
      (load local))
    editor))

just add to the respective *rc for your lisp implementation

When developing new functionality, it enables her to build programs first by performing small tasks manually, as if she were the computer, then gradually make them more and more automated, until the desired functionality is fully programmed. When debugging, the REPL makes the execution of her programs feel tangible: it enables the programmer to rapidly reproduce the problem, observe its symptoms closely, then improvise experiments to rapidly narrow down the cause of the bug and iterate towards a fix.
even if you don't like emacs, interactive clojure solutions for vim like conjure exist which says a lot about the appeal
obviously lisp without interactive dev is still lisp, if you really want to do the old fashioned save-and-make that's your prerogative, but it's still worth mentioning

#lang sicp

(define (inc x) (+ x 1))
(define (identity x) x)

(define (accumulate combiner null-value term a next b)
  (if (> a b)
      null-value
      (combiner (term a)
                (accumulate term (next a) next b))))

(define (product term a next b)
  (accumulate * 1 term a next b))
(define (sum term a next b)
  (accumulate + 0 term a next b))

one of the first functions I added to my config, years ago, was this, probably taken from SO:
(defun samedi/eval-and-replace ()
  "Replaces the preceding sexp with its value."
  (interactive)
  (backward-kill-sexp)
  (condition-case nil
      (prin1 (eval (read (current-kill 0))) (current-buffer))
    (error
     (message "Invalid expression.")
     (insert (current-kill 0)))))


I have it bound to C-c e. it turns all buffers into editable REPLs, on any mode

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90757813
If only it were only that. Graham's books (in particular, ANSI Common Lisp) are full of outright incorrect information (for instance, see the chapter on LOOP), you're better off avoiding it altogether.

As crazy as it may sound, my unorthodox advice is to actually read the ANSI CL standard and largely ignore introductory books. It is the ultimate authority on how the language actually works and it is the least opinionated document you could ever find on it.

Of course, there is no substitute for practical experience. Reading is just one piece of the puzzle, you have to actually write programs in the language in order to truly learn it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90756287
Because the former gives you more possibilities. You have variable-sized and proportional fonts, better mouse support, images, more colors, toolbars, menubars, context menus, ability to distinguish character sequences outside of the limitations of termcaps and also a full terminal emulator inside it. Running Emacs in a terminal emulator loses all of these features.

Still, I generally run an entirely separate terminal emulator most of the time, I usually only run a shell directly within Emacs at most.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90758294
>Of course, there is no substitute for practical experience. Reading is just one piece of the puzzle, you have to actually write programs in the language in order to truly learn it.
You can get far by just doing some exercises on exercism and reading other people's solutions there.
Programming books are helpful if it's your first language or they're about algorithms or some other general computer science concept.
If you know how to program in general, you just need to get used to the syntax by writing a bit when encountering a new language.

As special as Lisp is, it's not that hard to get started. You can pick up the unique bits as you go.
I don't know how many times I've said this in this thread, but any book that pretends to teach you something without giving you *plenty* of exercises deserves to be thrown in the trash. It is not worth anyone's time and we should aggressively disparage it.

the problem is geiser believes you'll be working with multiple different scheme REPLs at the same time, so it doesn't commit to anything. the behavior I wanted is:
>run M-x geiser
>it asks me to pick an implementation
>it opens a REPL for that implementation
>associates the current buffer with the recently opened REPL
>optionally, associate all scheme buffers with that REPL

1-3 happen, but not 4 or 5. if I call geiser-eval-buffer on the buffer I was viewing when I started geiser, it will say "no REPL for this buffer!" unless the REPL is the one defined by geiser-default-implementation. I have to call geiser-set-scheme and choose an implementation manually, then it works

>>90767719
> Why are compilers special in the bottomless well of complexity

They're not, but you should try to learn something about each level, it's incredibly rewarding. Also, the well isn't bottomless, and compilers are an important rung in the ladder. The well stops when you learn to convert binary into logic gates in cpu architecture, and tie that back to symbolic logic, which is the most rewarding thing I learned for my degree.

>>90767537
> Maybe learn web dev if you're not already familiar with it
Chances are they already do that at work. Web dev is one of the least inspiring things to work with desu, and I'm glad I do it as work because I sure as shit am not wasting a second of my spare time in that world
> Or some standard UNIX shit like C, shell, sed, awk, perl etc.
Again, that stuff doesn't take that long to learn. I already know how to do everything I'll ever need to do on the commandline. The idea is to then move on to something that helps you understand your ecosystem better.
> Or look into Clojure and JVM
Clojure is neat because it lets you somewhat escape from the world of webshit while still ultimately writing webshit, but that's about it. I wish it were more like CL, and it's tool stack is the most bloated thing that I try to use for any project. I appreciate what the community has built here, but I can't say I enjoy using the JVM ecosystem.

Basically, all your recommendations are either pretty surface level or tied into the world of webshit, which is not everyone's cup of tea. You're getting backlash here because your definition of 'useful' precludes a lot of the most interesting things about using an actual computer.

posts.com:
Anyone want to help me out with sicp 1.39? I am doing it recursively, counting up to k.
#lang sicp

; compute a k-term finite continuous fraction

(define (cont-frac n d k)
  (define (try i)
    (if (= i k)
        (/ (n i) (d i))
        (/ (n i) (+ (d i) (try (inc i))))))
  (try 1))

; calculate tan(x) as a k-term finite continuous fraction
(define (tan-cf x k)
  (cont-frac (lambda (i)
               (if (= i 1)
                   x
                   (* x x -1)))
             (lambda (i)
               (if (= i 1)
                   0
                   (- (* 2.0 (- i 1)) 1)))
             k))

(tan-cf 3.14 100)

I'm not getting accurate answers and the only other recursive solution I found doesn't work correctly either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90774311
nvm, fixed it.
(define (tan-cf x k)
  (/ x
     (+ 1
        (cont-frac (lambda (i)
                     (- (* x x)))
                   (lambda (i)
                     (+ 1 (* 2 i)))
                   k))))

i just used to think more steps = better result but the reality is past a certain amount of steps on different samplers whats 'better' is not always the best thing and it takes a fuck load longer

euler a = 17-20 steps
dpm++ 2 a karras = 25-30 steps
DDIM = 25-40 steps

this has been my personal guideline for a while to get results i like

>>90775417
100 is ridiculously high for anything, most samplers converge at a peak of quality/cohesiveness near enough ~30 at most and from there are just meaninglessly swapping shit around. but for ancestral solvers it's even more pointless because not only are they basically at a peak of quality by ~20, they also don't converge and just keep changing their form hugely, so you can't even lie to yourself that the sampler is slowly cleaning up trash with the extra steps
>>90775432
>>90775450
I have about the same view as you on step counts, w/ that said there's not much difference between samplers so i just leave mine as dpm++ 2m karras (which from a bunch of X/Y testing seemed to be fractionally better, and also is a favourite of many anons) 100% of the time at around 25 steps, 35 if on very complex compositions. whiny guys needs to shut up also

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90775450
The trick with Euler a (and at least one other sampler, I don't remember) is that they're essentially recursive. You are unlikely to cook an output with Euler a no matter how many samples you actually do, it's just a waste of resources and it'll keep cycling through. It could be a supra-seed way of getting new outputs.
