>>90775884
>If anything, they're probably just more upset over people using it for commercial reasons instead of a tool

That’s absolutely it. When I talk to the real artists who are concerned about it, explain the process, and how a lot more work goes into it than a lot of what is considered “modern art”, they actually chill out about it completely and become interested.

The ones that are really rough, are the disingenuous “artists” who pretend to care about it being trained of peoples work without their permission. When you break down that argument and why it’s wrong, they’ll switch to the real issue, the loss of potential business. They’d rather kill this in the water denying everyone the biggest advancement for creative expression in our lifetimes than have it threaten their perceived business opportunities and it’s a revolting thing to watch. You can easily tell who loves art, and who uses it primarily for business and attention, and like I said, the great irony is that if these people somehow managed to get what they wanted (ie: stronger copyright laws) they’d only be hurting themselves and the people in big companies would still be replacing them.

>>90776073
The funny thing is, art lost all meaning with the modern art movement. People want to argue if AI art is art or not, when the act of me taping a banana to a wall is art. Me pooping on a canvas and smearing it around is art. If I throw up dye I ingested on a piece of paper? Art. I see some artists trying to fight over the definition of if it’s art as if the title of being art holds any meaning at all anymore. There was a fight to be had a long time ago, but that fight wasn’t fought or was and horribly lost. Now the labels of “art” and “artist” don’t mean a thing, and as an artist (in the traditional sense) of two decades, I can say there’s a lot more that goes into creating a good piece of AI art than a lot of what is considered modern art.

>>90770940

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90770940
Because they are one of the ultimate examples of a watchmaker that was great in the pre-quartz era that--as a result of the quartz crisis--ended up getting turned into the ultimate overpriced mall watch shitter brand of the 1990s (i.e. the modern nadir of watchmaking).

TAG went all in on pandering to normies who know nothing about watches using marketing to get them into the store so they could flog them wildly overpriced shitters with generic cheap movements in them. Their modern designs are all designed to appeal to normie aesthetic tastes in watches, also.

This makes them a brand with essentially zero modern horological value outside of their re-issues of vintage designs from before Heuer was ruined.

>>90768977
Officials are stumped.

No shit. Government employees are fucking retarded.

It's likely an SLA battery cause that panel would only output about 12W at best, so doubtful it would be a LiFEPo4

The mast antenna is likely an omni and the white box is a patch.

Can't tell what freq it's running without an RF wand, but you could crack open the mast and measure the copper to figure out the wavelength, I'm guessing it's a 1/4 wave monopole on the omni.

Potential use cases are many:

It could be a repeater, but the diversity of both an omnidirectional and a directional antenna makes this unlikely since the directional has far less attenuation.

It could be LoraWAN for helium mining but the current ROI for those is insane where some people have 100s running and aren't making any decent returns because (surprise surprise) the entire network is just miners, no one is actually using the IOT capability of the system.

It could be a rescue system, the omni picks up signals and the patches use beam forming to transmit to a receiver (again, precise data such as angles or magnitudes would allow to triangulate a target).

But as always, the intelligent people don't waste their time with this shit and leave it to the tards who go "dunno. Must be crypto related. Case solved"

Kali Linux is a free and open-source Linux distribution that is widely used for digital forensics, penetration testing, and security research. It is developed and maintained by Offensive Security, a cybersecurity training company, and is based on the Debian operating system.

One of the main features of Kali Linux is its extensive collection of tools for these purposes, which includes tools for network analysis, vulnerability scanning, password cracking, and more. It also includes a custom desktop environment and various customizations, such as additional repositories for software packages and a custom kernel.

Kali Linux is designed to be run on a wide range of hardware, including personal computers, laptops, and network appliances. It is available for download from the Offensive Security website and can be installed on a hard drive or run from a live USB or DVD.

Why ThinkPad?
>Used machines are plentiful and cheap
>Excellent keyboards, tactile feel and quiet
>Great durability: magnesium roll cage for structural integrity, with high quality plastic body panels
>Utilitarian design: e.g. indicator LEDs, 7 row keyboard layout on older models

>Easy to repair (most models), upgrade & maintain thanks to readily available service manuals for every model, spare parts easy & cheap to obtain
>Excellent Linux & *BSD support

ThinkWiki - General info about ThinkPads/specs
https://www.thinkwiki.org/wiki/ThinkWiki

Classic models:
>X220/X230 - 12", 768p, cheap and light
>T420/T430 - 14", 900p (1080p w/mod board), Ivy Bridge support on T420 w/coreboot, quad core upgrade, classic keyboard mod on xx30 series
>T520/530; W520/530 - 15", 1080p, DTR, 32GB RAM on quad core models
>T440p/540p; W540/1 - last ThinkPads with socketed processors, easily replaceable trackpad (W541 doesn't need trackpad replacement)
>T440s/T450(s)/T460(s)/T470(s) - ultraportables, good battery life
>T480 - last ThinkPad with swappable battery, T25 keyboard mod, excellent performance/battery life, getting cheaper

Upgraded models:
>X2100 - X200/X201
>X62/X63 - X61
>T700 - T60

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90775256

All creative works receive an automatic copyright, and that includes code. However, that just means people can't copy the code you posted here. It does not mean they can't implement their own code to accomplish the same task. If you want to use intellectual property laws to prevent other people from creating their own implementations of your idea, you need a patent, not a copyright. Unlike a copyright, you don't get these automatically, and you also need to pay a decent amount of money to get these filed. Furthermore, they can reject your application if they don't consider it sufficiently original.

>>90759683
Looking into it further, you're right. It seems that "jailbreak" refers to a custom ROM with a root user and port of Debian APT to install .deb packages, the end result a phone very similar to typical UNIX, plus the sideload/jailbreak patch. Various .deb packages exist to install the LAMP stack directly for example that their scene focuses on, while Android is more about these awkward .zip file bundles which I believe are mounted using mergerfs over /system, and xposed modules applied on boot using complex exploits, as the phone aggressively resets itself if you change anything with the typical Magisk systemless root solution these days, LAMP typically installed in an emulated shell in appspace instead for convenience, installers of patches feeling more like DOS than UNIX. I believe it's only this complicated due to Google barring phones from running certain apps via Safetynet if /system is ever written to, and the Android scene overengineering everything rather than cracking it. Using a rooted iPhone sounds refreshingly simple. Why doesn't anyone ever talk about it here? What's it like?

I got a GK75 off of KPRepublic because I was really interested by the idea of swapping out a segment of the plate for split-spacebar support, and for having pads set down to be able to hotswap knobs in an MX formfactor.

The steel plate included is stiffer than a camp counselor's cock, but despite that the board doesn't really feel much different than a gasket-mount to type on. Acoustics are good, it has triple-mode wireless, the knobs are customizable, Skyloong's driver software is pretty confusing as usual. It's about par for a $100 plastic board but it's got some really cool features if you're into customizing it, it's gonna be a bit before you find any other hotswap keyboards with split spacebar support, let alone something like hotswap knobs.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90749564
Updates on this keyboard, Skyloong GK75:
>It *is* gasket-mounted as advertised, but it is not a good gasket-mounting at all, very thin flaps of rubber that come up and over the plate from the silicone pad between the PCB and plate
>It's essentially tray-mounted, the PCB + plate assembly screws into standoffs molded into the bottom case
>It has a layer of foam inside the bottom case which is probably mostly to shield the two daughterboards that handle the USB-C port and the wireless, and the battery
>The spacebar split design is somewhat strangely split into three spacebars, the largest on the left, a slightly smaller one in the middle, and a Ctrl/Alt key sized one on the farthest right
>The knobs are T18 knurled but it'd probably be total hell to find another knob that fit, the shaft on the knob is insanely short to accommodate a molded plastic tube over it which fits the inserts on the knobs that the keyboard comes with. The knobs all have a guitar-style dial attached by default but it comes with two rounded GMMK Pro style knobs in a little baggy in case you want that style
>Box contains a C-female to A-female adapter, an A-male to C-male cable, split spacebar keys in Skyloong's GK2 rubber keycap profile, extra screws and knob heads, the switch-plate segment for split spacebar, a plastic dust cover, and a keycap/switch puller
>No complaints about the stabilizers at all! Stabs came pre-installed on both sets of spacebar plates, no rattle, all stabs are lubed from factory and they have a pretty good lube-job
>There's a QR code on the keyboard to download the shitty Epomaker/Skyloong customization software straight from its page, which is handy
I'm very pleased with it for the $79 asking price! I'll happily recommend it for anybody who wants an exploded 75% with knob, or wants a wireless 75%. You can get rid of the knob quickly and easily if you don't want it, or put on more knobs if you want more knobs. Also comes as an 1800 version called the GK980.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I'm trying to use Linux Mint for some basic gaming with an AMD APU, what do I need to look for? Just make sure I have an updated version of Mesa drivers through a trustworthy PPA?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90772369
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:kisak/kisak-mesa && sudo dpkg --add-architecture i386 && sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade && sudo apt install libgl1-mesa-dri:i386 mesa-vulkan-drivers mesa-vulkan-drivers:i386

Run this command and you should be all set.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90772388
Also you gotta restart after you run it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90772388
Thank you, bro! For learning purposes: is it kinda like I posted? It seems like a PPA is added and Mesa drivers are being installed from it, plus enabling 32bit architecture. I'm a newbie, so I'm not sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90772418
Yes, it's adding the Kisak Mesa repo which has the most up to date Mesa drivers for Ubuntu-based systems, telling dpkg to add 32-bit architecture support, updating the repo sources, fully upgrading anything that can be upgraded then installs the Mesa and Vulkan drivers from the Kisak repo. Then like I said just restart the PC and you should be all good for gaming.

>deleting stuff outside pwd
Assuming both folders you mentioned are in your home directory (/home/user) it would be 
rm -r ~/Documents/'Testicle Boxing'

and 
rm -r ~/Videos/Abuela

If they have files/folders inside of them, otherwise replace the rm -r for rmdir.
~ is a shortcut to your home directory. You could also use absolute paths (/home/user/Documents/etc) or relative paths:
Pretend you're in ~/Downloads, you can type .. to go up a folder so from ~/Downloads you would enter
rm -r ../Documents/'Testicle Boxing'

It's actually the safest way to dual-boot if you want to install the Linux distro on a separate drive to your Windows one. That way the Windows one doesn't get pissy about it sharing space with another OS.
Just make sure that you're installing Linux to the fresh other drive which you can easily see by looking at the drives in something like gparted or the Ubuntu installer. You'll know which one is which by the MS partitions on whatever drive, which'll probably be /dev/sda or /dev/nvme01n1 if it's an M.2 SSD.

I have given it non-nonsensical things to make and it has done it.

>Write me a Rust program that generates a HLSL shader

>Sure! Here is a simple Rust program that generates an HLSL shader that shades a triangle using the Phong reflection model:

fn main() {
    let vertex_shader = r#"
        struct VertexInput {
            float3 position : POSITION;
            float3 normal : NORMAL;
        };

        struct PixelInput {
            float4 position : SV_POSITION;
            float3 normal : NORMAL;
        };

        PixelInput main(VertexInput input) {
            PixelInput output;
            output.position = float4(input.position, 1.0);
            output.normal = input.normal;
            return output;
        }
    "#;

    let fragment_shader = r#"
        struct PixelInput {
            float4 position : SV_POSITION;
            float3 normal : NORMAL;
        };

        float4 main(PixelInput input) : SV_TARGET {
            float3 light_direction = normalize(float3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0));
            float3 view_direction = normalize(float3(0.0, 0.0, 1.0));
            float3 half_direction = normalize(light_direction + view_direction);

            float diffuse = max(dot(input.normal, light_direction), 0.0);
            float specular = pow(max(dot(input.normal, half_direction), 0.0), 64.0);

            float3 color = float3(0.5, 0.5, 0.5) * diffuse + float3(0.5, 0.5, 0.5) * specular;
            return float4(color, 1.0);
        }
    "#;

    println!("Vertex shader:
{}
", vertex_shader);
    println!("Fragment shader:
{}
", fragment_shader);
}

>>90772266
When you use dreambooth you are replacing some of the existing data, not adding to it. Mixes with dreambooth models will forget more and more of the original breadth of SD and become very narrow in their output. LoRA is a separate file and doesn't damage the original model, and doesn't need to carry all the rest of the original model data with it either.

>>90769591
>he doesnt know
Nec TOKINS are a failure point, but aren't the main thing killing PS3s for good. Its the BGA "bumps" in the 90nm and 65nm nvidia silicon that kills PS3s. Its something that effects literally every nvidia product on those nodes and isn't really fixable. The only fix is to do a frankenmod, where you swap out the dead RSX with a late model 65nm or 40nm RSX. This isn't some community made agreement either, if you had a affected PS3 and sent it to sony, they would do the same thing.
https://youtu.be/Za7WTNwAX0c?t=1639
tldr Tokins are a temporary fix, if you have a 65nm RSX or older, the PS3 is basically guaranteed to die someday.

posts.sub: Twitter hacked, 200 million user email addresses leaked, researcher says
posts.com:
LONDON, Jan 5 (Reuters) - Hackers stole the email addresses of more than 200 million Twitter users and posted them on an online hacking forum, a security researcher said Wednesday.

The breach “will unfortunately lead to a lot of hacking, targeted phishing and doxxing,” Alon Gal, co-founder of Israeli cybersecurity-monitoring firm Hudson Rock, wrote on LinkedIn. He called it “one of the most significant leaks I've seen.”

Twitter has not commented on the report, which Gal first posted about on social media on Dec. 24, nor responded to inquiries about the breach since that date. It was not clear what action, if any, Twitter has taken to investigate or remediate the issue.

Reuters could not independently verify the data on the forum was authentic and came from Twitter. Screenshots of the hacker forum, where the data appeared on Wednesday, have circulated online.

Troy Hunt, creator of breach-notification site Have I Been Pwned, viewed the leaked data and said on Twitter that it seemed “pretty much what it’s been described as.”

There were no clues to the identity or location of the hacker or hackers behind the breach. It may have taken place as early as 2021, which was before Elon Musk took over ownership of the company last year.

>https://www.reuters.com/technology/twitter-hacked-200-million-user-email-addresses-leaked-researcher-says-2023-01-05/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>saw a noticeable increase in performance in specific games that had it
That's the thing, the game engine has to be designed to use it and use it well or else it could easily become a bottleneck. Even if multi GPU setups were common, you would not only need to design your game around them, you would still likely need to design your game to support single-GPU setups because they would still be everywhere. Designing your engine to work optimally around every possible consumer setup is possible, but it's not what the AAA game industry is about. So when gamers failed to bite on the PhysX hook, game engine devs stopped designing for it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90771186
IIRC Physx leveraged the CUDA cores which are usually used for rasterization so having a dedicated physx card freed up the CUDA cores on the main card so they could work only on raster leading to better performance.

By contrast, ray tracing is performed on a new and separate type of core called the tensor cores which would be sitting idle if RT was turned off. So, no, having a dedicated RT card wouldn't really help with performance, there is already dedicated hardware on the card. PCIe also just doesn't have enough bandwidth for the amount of calculations performed in RT either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90771186
Using a dedicated graphics card for PhysX can indeed provide a performance boost in games that support it, but this approach is not very common nowadays. One reason for this is that newer graphics cards have more powerful CPUs and are generally able to handle both graphics rendering and physics calculations without much of a performance hit. Additionally, not many games these days support PhysX, so the demand for a dedicated PhysX card is not very high.

As for using a dedicated graphics card for ray tracing, it is possible to get a performance boost by using multiple graphics cards in this way. However, this approach would require the use of multiple graphics cards, which can be cost-prohibitive for some users. Additionally, the performance boost may not be as significant as you might expect, depending on the specific hardware and software setup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90771567
PCIe is no longer slow as fuck, but like HDMI/DP standards adoption, hardware migrating to new specs will always lag far behind and be met with arbitrary "new tech prices"

Consider that PCI v.4, at consumer avilability, is barely 3 years old. We're already at PCI v.5 for consumers, and v.6 is finalized and ready for hardware build. The massive time gap between PCIe3 and 4 was kind of an anomaly, anyways.

PCIe4 took ~2 years from spec finalization to mass consumer devices, PCIe5 took ~2.5 years, and PCIe6 was finalized 1 year ago.
PCIe6 will be on consumer motherboards/CPUs by ~2024, 2025 at the latest.

In less than 5 years we've gone from absolutely ancient PCIe rev.3 spec to looking at something 8 times the bandwidth just around the corner.
GPUs dont even need anywhere near that much because even with NVMEs they are bottlenecked by the small file transfer speed limitations.

But with the whole PCI bus bandwidth problem "solved" (not that you know how much finalized, post-processing data raytracing actually needs to send),
Multi-card is forever dead. It's too complicated to program for and the market size of people actually justifying/affording it is laughably small.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90773128
MacOS was the name of Apple's original ("Classic") OS for 68k and PowerPC Macs. Prior to 2015, "MacOS" referred to System 1 through OS9. The 68k version's kernel was written in Pascal and 68k assembly, and the PPC version used a mach-derived microkernel. It was not related to OSX.
OSX was unix based and used lots of code borrowed from BSD.
"MacOS" (versions 10.12 and up) is a rebadged OSX. It's the same OS under the hood.
This would be like if Microsoft renamed Windows 11 "Microsoft Plus" or something. It's Windows.
